maml:description.maml:para: Adds members to a local security group.

Adds members to a local security group. Local security groups are specific to individual computers. If the computer is not joined to a domain, you can add local user accounts to a local security group. If the computer is joined to a domain, you can add local user accounts, domain user accounts, computer accounts, and domain security groups from that domain and from trusted domains to a local security group.
Specifies the name of the local security group to which members will be added.

Specifies one or members to add to the local security group. You can specify members by name, security identifier (SID), or NetPrincipal objects. You can add a local security group as a member of another local security group on the same computer as a nested group, but this does not grant access to members of the nested group. For example, adding a local security group to the local Administrators security group on the same computer does not grant administrator access to the members of the nested group.

Specifies the computer name where the local security group resides. You cannot specify this parameter if you use the -Group parameter. Omit this parameter to add members to the local security group on the current computer.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the security identifier (SID) of the local security group to which members will be added.

Specifies one or members to add to the local security group. You can specify members by name, security identifier (SID), or NetPrincipal objects. You can add a local security group as a member of another local security group on the same computer as a nested group, but this does not grant access to members of the nested group. For example, adding a local security group to the local Administrators security group on the same computer does not grant administrator access to the members of the nested group.

Specifies the computer name where the local security group resides. You cannot specify this parameter if you use the -Group parameter. Omit this parameter to add members to the local security group on the current computer.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the local security group to which members will be added. Use Get-NetLocalGroup or Get-NetLocalAdminGroup to get a local security group for this parameter.

Specifies one or members to add to the local security group. You can specify members by name, security identifier (SID), or NetPrincipal objects. You can add a local security group as a member of another local security group on the same computer as a nested group, but this does not grant access to members of the nested group. For example, adding a local security group to the local Administrators security group on the same computer does not grant administrator access to the members of the nested group.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.

Specifies the computer name where the local security group resides. You cannot specify this parameter if you use the -Group parameter. Omit this parameter to add members to the local security group on the current computer.
Specifies the local security group to which members will be added. Use Get-NetLocalGroup or Get-NetLocalAdminGroup to get a local security group for this parameter.

Specifies one or members to add to the local security group. You can specify members by name, security identifier (SID), or NetPrincipal objects. You can add a local security group as a member of another local security group on the same computer as a nested group, but this does not grant access to members of the nested group. For example, adding a local security group to the local Administrators security group on the same computer does not grant administrator access to the members of the nested group.
Specifies the name of the local security group to which members will be added.
Specifies the security identifier (SID) of the local security group to which members will be added.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
You can pipe NetPrincipal objects to specify local security group members.
Returns no output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds members to the local Administrators security group on the current computer.
Adds the Domain Admins group from the FABRIKAM domain to the local Administrators security group on the current computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Disables local user accounts.
Disables local user accounts. Local user accounts are specific to individual computers.
Specifies one or more names of local user account(s) to disable. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies the computer name where the local user account(s) reside. Omit this parameter to disable local user accounts on the current computer.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies one or more security idetifiers (SIDs) of local user account(s) to disable.
Specifies the computer name where the local user account(s) reside. Omit this parameter to disable local user accounts on the current computer.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies one or more local user account(s) to disable.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the computer name where the local user account(s) reside. Omit this parameter to disable local user accounts on the current computer.
Specifies one or more local user account(s) to disable.
Specifies one or more names of local user account(s) to disable. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies one or more security idetifiers (SIDs) of local user account(s) to disable.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
You can pipe NetLocalUserPrincipal objects to specify the local user accounts.
You can pipe strings to specify the names of local user accounts.
You can pipe SecurityIdentifier objects to specify the security IDs of local user accounts.
Returns no output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Disables a local user account by specifying its name.

This command gets the local Guest user account by using Get-NetLocalUser, and then passes it to the Disable-NetLocalUser cmdlet by using the pipeline operator (|), which disables the local user account.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables local user accounts.
Enables local user accounts. Local user accounts are specific to individual computers.
Specifies one or more names of local user account(s) to enable. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies the computer name where the local user account(s) reside. Omit this parameter to enable local user accounts on the current computer.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies one or more security idetifiers (SIDs) of local user account(s) to enable.
Specifies the computer name where the local user account(s) reside. Omit this parameter to enable local user accounts on the current computer.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies one or more local user account(s) to enable.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the computer name where the local user account(s) reside. Omit this parameter to enable local user accounts on the current computer.
Specifies one or more local user account(s) to enable.
Specifies one or more names of local user account(s) to enable. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies one or more security idetifiers (SIDs) of local user account(s) to enable.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
You can pipe NetLocalUserPrincipal objects to specify the local user accounts.
You can pipe strings to specify the names of local user accounts.
You can pipe SecurityIdentifier objects to specify the security IDs of local user accounts.
Returns no output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Enables a local user account by specifying its name.

This command gets the local Administrator user account by using Get-NetLocalUser, and then passes it to the Enable-NetLocalUser cmdlet by using the pipeline operator (|), which enables the local user account.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the local Administrators security group.
Gets the local Administrators security group. The local Administrators security group has the security identifier (SID) S-1-5-32-544.
Specifies one or more computer names. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get the local Administrators security group on the current computer.
Specifies one or more computer names. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get the local Administrators security group on the current computer.
You can pipe strings to specify computer names.
Outputs NetLocalGroupPrincipal objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the local Administrators security group (SID S-1-5-32-544) on the current computer. This command is equivalent to 'Get-NetLocalGroup -SID S-1-5-32-544'. The command outputs properties of the local Administrators security group.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the local Administrator user account.
Gets the local Administrator user account. The security identifier (SID) of a computer's local Administrator user account is the computer's SID with the relative identifier (RID) 500.
Specifies one or more computer names. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get the local Administrator user account on the current computer.
Specifies one or more computer names. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get the local Administrator user account on the current computer.
You can pipe strings to specify computer names.
Outputs NetLocalUserPrincipal objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the local Administrator user account (RID 500) on the current computer. This command is equivalent to 'Get-NetLocalUser | Where-Object { $_.SID.Value.EndsWith("-500") }', except that it is more efficient because it retrieves the local Administrator user account on the computer directly without needing the Where-Object filter. The command outputs properties of the local Administrator user account.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets local security groups.
Gets local security groups. Local security groups are specific to individual computers.
Specifies one or more names of local security groups. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get all local security groups.
Specifies the computer name where the local security groups reside. Omit this parameter to get local security groups on the current computer.
Specifies one or more security identifiers (SIDs) of local security groups.
Specifies the computer name where the local security groups reside. Omit this parameter to get local security groups on the current computer.
Specifies the computer name where the local security groups reside. Omit this parameter to get local security groups on the current computer.
Specifies one or more names of local security groups. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get all local security groups.
Specifies one or more security identifiers (SIDs) of local security groups.
You can pipe strings to specify local security group names.
You can pipe SecurityIdentifier objects to specify security IDs for local security groups.
Outputs NetLocalGroupPrincipal objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets a local security group on the current computer. The command outputs properties of the local security group.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets members of local security groups.
Gets members of local security groups. Local security groups are specific to individual computers.
Specifies one or more names of local security groups. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies the computer name where the local security groups reside. Omit this parameter to get the members of local security groups on the current computer.
Specifies one or more security security identifiers (SIDs) of local security groups.
Specifies the computer name where the local security groups reside. Omit this parameter to get the members of local security groups on the current computer.
Specifies one or more local security groups.
Specifies the computer name where the local security groups reside. Omit this parameter to get the members of local security groups on the current computer.
Specifies one or more local security groups.
Specifies one or more names of local security groups. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies one or more security security identifiers (SIDs) of local security groups.

dev:type.maml:name: You can pipe NetLocalGroupPrincipal objects to specify local security groups.

maml:description.maml:para: You can pipe strings to specify the local security group names.
You can pipe SecurityIdentifier objects to specify the local security group SIDs.
Outputs NetPrincipal objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the members of a local security group on the current computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets local user accounts.
Gets local user accounts. Local user accounts are specific to individual computers.
Specifies one or more names of local user accounts. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get all local user accounts.
Specifies the computer name where the local user accounts reside. Omit this parameter to get local user accounts on the current computer.
Specifies one or more security identifiers (SIDs) of local user accounts.
Specifies the computer name where the local user accounts reside. Omit this parameter to get local user accounts on the current computer.
Specifies the computer name where the local user accounts reside. Omit this parameter to get local user accounts on the current computer.
Specifies one or more names of local user accounts. Wildcards are not permitted. Omit this parameter to get all local user accounts.
Specifies one or more security identifiers (SIDs) of local user accounts.
You can pipe strings to specify local user account names.
You can pipe SecurityIdentifier objects to specify security IDs for local user accounts.
Outputs NetLocalUserPrincipal objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the local user account on the current computer. The command outputs properties of the local user account.
Gets the local user account by its security identifier (SID). The command outputs properties of the local user account.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets well-known principals.

Gets well-known principals. Some examples of well-known principals are the built-in Administrators group (SID S-1-5-32-544, type 'BuiltinGroup') and the SYSTEM account (SID S-1-5-18, type 'WellKnown'). For more information, see the Microsoft help topic titled "Well-known SIDs."
Gets the Domain Admins group principals for the domain name(s) specified by this parameter.
Specifies one or more names of well-known principals. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies one or more security identifiers (SIDs) of well-known principals.
Gets the Domain Admins group principals for the domain name(s) specified by this parameter.
Specifies one or more names of well-known principals. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies one or more security identifiers (SIDs) of well-known principals.
You can pipe strings to specify well-known principal names.
You can pipe SecurityIdentifier objects to specify security IDs for well-known principals.
Outputs NetPrincipal objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the NetPrincipal object for the SYSTEM account (SID S-1-5-18). The command outputs properties of the NetPrincipal object.
Gets the NetPrincipal object for the Administrators built-in group. The command outputs properties of the NetPrincipal object.
Gets the NetPrincipal object for the Domain Admins group in the FABRIKAM domain. The command outputs properties of the NetPrincipal object.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a local security group.
Creates a local security group. Local security groups are specific to individual computers.
Specifies a name for the local security group.
Specifies the computer name where to create the local security group. Omit this parameter to create the local security group on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local security group.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the computer name where to create the local security group. Omit this parameter to create the local security group on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local security group.
Specifies a name for the local security group.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
You can a string to specify a local security group name.
Outputs a NetLocalGroupPrincipal object for the group.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS > New-NetLocalGroup "Application Admins" -Description "Members of this group can administer applications."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new local security group on the current computer with the specified name and description.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a local user account.
Creates a local user account. Local user accounts are specific to individual computers.
Specifies a name for the local user account.

Specifies the date and time when the local user account expires. Account expiration specifies a date and time after which the account cannot log on. If you don't specify this parameter, the account doesn't expire. Account expiration is different from password expiration. The account expiration date and time cannot be later than 6 February 2106 6:28:14 UTC.

Specifies the system will require a password change at the first logon. The default value for this parameter is $true, so to disable it, you must specify -ChangePasswordAtLogon:$false. You cannot specify -ChangePasswordAtLogon with -PasswordNeverExpires or -UserMayNotChangePassword.
Specifies the computer name where to create the local user account. Omit this parameter to create the local user account on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local user account.
Specifies that the local user account will be created in a disabled state.
Specifies the full name for the local user account. The full name differs from the user name of the local user account.
Specifies the path to the user's account's home directory. You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.

Specifies a drive that is associated with the UNC path defined by the HomeDirectory property. The drive letter is specified as '<Letter>:' where '<Letter>' indicates the letter of the drive to associate. The drive letter must be a single uppercase letter and the colon is required.
Specifies to create the local user account without a password. Note that this will fail if security policies require a password to be specified.
Specifies that the local user account's password does not expire. You cannot specify both -PasswordNeverExpires and -ChangePasswordAtLogon.
Specifies that the local user account requires a password. The default value for this parameter is $true, so to disable it, you must specify -PasswordRequired:$false.
Specifies the path to the local user account's profile. You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.
Specifies the path to the local user account's logon script file.
Specifies that the local user account cannot change the password of the account. You cannot specify both -UserMayNotChangePassword and -ChangePasswordAtLogon.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies a name for the local user account.

Specifies the date and time when the local user account expires. Account expiration specifies a date and time after which the account cannot log on. If you don't specify this parameter, the account doesn't expire. Account expiration is different from password expiration. The account expiration date and time cannot be later than 6 February 2106 6:28:14 UTC.

Specifies the system will require a password change at the first logon. The default value for this parameter is $true, so to disable it, you must specify -ChangePasswordAtLogon:$false. You cannot specify -ChangePasswordAtLogon with -PasswordNeverExpires or -UserMayNotChangePassword.
Specifies the computer name where to create the local user account. Omit this parameter to create the local user account on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local user account.
Specifies that the local user account will be created in a disabled state.
Specifies the full name for the local user account. The full name differs from the user name of the local user account.
Specifies the path to the user's account's home directory. You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.

Specifies a drive that is associated with the UNC path defined by the HomeDirectory property. The drive letter is specified as '<Letter>:' where '<Letter>' indicates the letter of the drive to associate. The drive letter must be a single uppercase letter and the colon is required.
Specifies the password for the local user account. If you omit the -Password and -NoPassword parameters, New-NetLocalUser will prompt for the new local user account's password.
Specifies that the local user account's password does not expire. You cannot specify both -PasswordNeverExpires and -ChangePasswordAtLogon.
Specifies that the local user account requires a password. The default value for this parameter is $true, so to disable it, you must specify -PasswordRequired:$false.
Specifies the path to the local user account's profile. You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.
Specifies the path to the local user account's logon script file.
Specifies that the local user account cannot change the password of the account. You cannot specify both -UserMayNotChangePassword and -ChangePasswordAtLogon.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.

Specifies the date and time when the local user account expires. Account expiration specifies a date and time after which the account cannot log on. If you don't specify this parameter, the account doesn't expire. Account expiration is different from password expiration. The account expiration date and time cannot be later than 6 February 2106 6:28:14 UTC.

Specifies the system will require a password change at the first logon. The default value for this parameter is $true, so to disable it, you must specify -ChangePasswordAtLogon:$false. You cannot specify -ChangePasswordAtLogon with -PasswordNeverExpires or -UserMayNotChangePassword.
Specifies the computer name where to create the local user account. Omit this parameter to create the local user account on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local user account.
Specifies that the local user account will be created in a disabled state.
Specifies the full name for the local user account. The full name differs from the user name of the local user account.
Specifies the path to the user's account's home directory. You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.

Specifies a drive that is associated with the UNC path defined by the HomeDirectory property. The drive letter is specified as '<Letter>:' where '<Letter>' indicates the letter of the drive to associate. The drive letter must be a single uppercase letter and the colon is required.
Specifies a name for the local user account.
Specifies to create the local user account without a password. Note that this will fail if security policies require a password to be specified.
Specifies the password for the local user account. If you omit the -Password and -NoPassword parameters, New-NetLocalUser will prompt for the new local user account's password.
Specifies that the local user account's password does not expire. You cannot specify both -PasswordNeverExpires and -ChangePasswordAtLogon.
Specifies that the local user account requires a password. The default value for this parameter is $true, so to disable it, you must specify -PasswordRequired:$false.
Specifies the path to the local user account's profile. You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.
Specifies the path to the local user account's logon script file.
Specifies that the local user account cannot change the password of the account. You cannot specify both -UserMayNotChangePassword and -ChangePasswordAtLogon.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
You can pipe a string to specify a local user account name.
Outputs a NetLocalUserPrincipal object for the local user account.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS > New-NetLocalUser -Name User02 -Description "Description of this account." -NoPassword

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new local user account on the current computer.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS > New-NetLocalUser User03 -FullName "Third User" -Description "Description of this account."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new local user account on the current computer. The command will prompt for the user account's password.

Specifies the name of the local user account to rename. Wildcards are not permitted.

Specifies the security identifier (SID) of the local user account to rename.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
You can pipe a NetLocalUserPrincipal object to specify the local user account.
You can pipe a string to specify the name of the local user account.
You can pipe a SecurityIdentifier object to specify the security ID of the local user account.
Returns no output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Renames a local user account on the current computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes local security groups.
Changes local security groups. Local security groups are specific to individual computers.
Specifies the name of the local security group to change. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies the computer name where the local security group resides. Omit this parameter to change the local security group on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local security group.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the security identifier (SID) of the local security group to change.
Specifies the computer name where the local security group resides. Omit this parameter to change the local security group on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local security group.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the local security group to change.
Specifies a description for the local security group.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the computer name where the local security group resides. Omit this parameter to change the local security group on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local security group.
Specifies the local security group to change.
Specifies the name of the local security group to change. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies the security identifier (SID) of the local security group to change.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
You can pipe NetLocalGroupPrincipal objects to specify local security groups.
You can pipe strings to specify local security group names.
You can pipe SecurityIdentifier objects to specify security IDs of local security groups.
Returns no output.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS > Set-NetLocalGroup "Application Admins" -Description "Members of this group can administer applications."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the description for a local security group on the current computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes local user accounts.
Changes local user accounts. Local user accounts are specific to individual computers.
Specifies the name of the local user account to change. Wildcards are not permitted.

Specifies the date and time when the local user account expires. Account expiration specifies a date and time after which the account cannot log on. Account expiration is different from password expiration. You cannot specify both -AccountExpires and -AccountNeverExpires. The account expiration date and time cannot be later than 6 February 2106 6:28:14 UTC.
Specifies that the local user account does not expire. You cannot specify both -AccountNeverExpires and -AccountExpires.

Specifies the system will require a password change at the next logon. You cannot specify '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true' with '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' or '-UserMayChangePassword $false'. If the account's PasswordNeverExpires property is $true, specifying '-ChangePasswordAtLogon -$true' will set the account's PasswordNeverExpires property to $false. If the account's UserMayChangePassword property is $false, specifying '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true' will set the account's UserMayChangePassword property to $true.
Specifies the computer name where the local user account resides. Omit this parameter change the local user account on the current computer.
Specifies a description for the local user account.
Specifies the full name for the local user account. The full name differs from the user name of the local user account.
Specifies the path to the user's home directory. This can be an empty string (""). You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.

Specifies a drive that is associated with the UNC path defined by the HomeDirectory property. The drive letter is specified as '<Letter>:' where '<Letter>' indicates the letter of the drive to associate. The drive letter must be a single uppercase letter and the colon is required. Specify an empty string ("") to specify "no home drive."
Specifies the password for the local user account.

Specifies whether the local user account's password never expires. You cannot specify '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' with '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true'. If the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property is $true, specifying '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' will set the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property to $false.
Specifies whether the local user account requires a password.
Specifies the path to the local user account's profile. This can be an empty string (""). You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.
Specifies the path to the local user account's logon script file. This can be an empty string ("").

Specifies whether the local user account can change the password of the account. You cannot specify '-UserMayChangePassword $false' and '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true'. If the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property is $true, specifying '-UserMayChangePassword $false' will set the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property to $false.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.
Specifies the security identifier (SID) of the user account to change.

Specifies the date and time when the local user account expires. Account expiration specifies a date and time after which the account cannot log on. Account expiration is different from password expiration. You cannot specify both -AccountExpires and -AccountNeverExpires. The account expiration date and time cannot be later than 6 February 2106 6:28:14 UTC.
Specifies that the local user account does not expire. You cannot specify both -AccountNeverExpires and -AccountExpires.

Specifies the system will require a password change at the next logon. You cannot specify '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true' with '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' or '-UserMayChangePassword $false'. If the account's PasswordNeverExpires property is $true, specifying '-ChangePasswordAtLogon -$true' will set the account's PasswordNeverExpires property to $false. If the account's UserMayChangePassword property is $false, specifying '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true' will set the account's UserMayChangePassword property to $true.

Specifies a description for the local user account.
Specifies the full name for the local user account. The full name differs from the user name of the local user account.

The drive letter is specified as '<Letter>:' where '<Letter>' indicates the letter of the drive to associate. The drive letter must be a single uppercase letter and the colon is required. Specify an empty string ("") to specify "no home drive."
Specifies the password for the local user account.

Specifies whether the local user account's password never expires. You cannot specify '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' with '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true'. If the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property is $true, specifying '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' will set the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property to $false.
Specifies whether the local user account requires a password.
Specifies the path to the local user account's profile. This can be an empty string (""). You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.
Specifies the path to the local user account's logon script file. This can be an empty string ("").

Specifies whether the local user account can change the password of the account. You cannot specify '-UserMayChangePassword $false' and '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true'. If the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property is $true, specifying '-UserMayChangePassword $false' will set the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property to $false.
Prompts for confirmation before taking an action.
Shows what action would be taken without taking the action.

If the account's PasswordNeverExpires property is $true, specifying '-ChangePasswordAtLogon -$true' will set the account's PasswordNeverExpires property to $false. If the account's UserMayChangePassword property is $false, specifying '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true' will set the account's UserMayChangePassword property to $true.

Specifies the path to the user's home directory. This can be an empty string (""). You can use '%username%' in this string to represent the user account's name.

The drive letter is specified as '<Letter>:' where '<Letter>' indicates the letter of the drive to associate. The drive letter must be a single uppercase letter and the colon is required. Specify an empty string ("") to specify "no home drive."
Specifies the local user account to change.
Specifies the name of the local user account to change. Wildcards are not permitted.
Specifies the password for the local user account.

Specifies whether the local user account's password never expires. You cannot specify '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' with '-ChangePasswordAtLogon $true'. If the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property is $true, specifying '-PasswordNeverExpires $true' will set the account's ChangePasswordAtLogon property to $false.
